channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Let’s do an experiment! Perl role in Canberra, Australia
item.description: Attention, Perl programmers. We’re looking for those among you who loved their childhood chemistry sets and could spend hours studying their ant farms. Science buffs and genetics junkies, our client wants to hear from you.

item.title: Scrooge had it right! Perl role in Vienna
item.description: Our client is one of the largest product and price comparison platforms in German-speaking countries. They’re not saying you shouldn’t spend money, but if you’re going to splash out on the latest gear, why not get the best price? Client is willing to consider all candidates with strong Perl, but they make heavy use of PostgreSQL, Elasticsearch, and Modern Perl.

item.title: What would your computer say about you? Perl, Python, NLP role in Amsterdam
item.description: Our client is the worldwide leader in machine intelligence for matching people with jobs, which is to say that when it comes to hiring, they know what they’re doing. Applicants, bring your “A” game: they’re looking for a Natural Language Processing (NLP) Engineer with Perl and Python.

item.title: Change the world without leaving your desk! Remote Perl role - UK, Switzerland or South Africa
item.description: As a thriving multinational fundraising group, our client works with thousands of charities to provide cloud-based management tools to connect with their supporters. If you have experience with payment systems and your Perl game is on point, we want to hear from you.

item.title: Pop Quiz and Your New Perl Role! 100% Remote within UK
item.description: Not feeling the urge to commute during these socially distanced times and beyond? Not a problem. The role is 100% remote-friendly for folks in the UK. The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks. If you’re a crack-hand with Catalyst, a Mojolicious master, or a distinguished Dancer, they want you.

item.title: Testing a Docker image created by GitLab CI
NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 126
item.description: Simon kept the narrative short and to the point as always. Keep it up.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 126: Count Sweeper
item.description: Roger made the Minesweeper Game so simple and that is the power of his algorithm. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 126
item.description: Once again Luis showing the power of PDL while dealing with Minesweeper Game. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 126: counting mines.
item.description: Luca solution to Minesweeper Game is easy to read and follow. I liked the simplicity. Keep up the great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 126: Count Numbers and Minesweeper Game
item.description: Laurent has been sharing Perl and Raku solutions every week for months now. If you ever want to learn how to port Raku solution to Perl then this is the best place to look at. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #126
item.description: James love for performance matrix is always the first thing I notice. It tells a complete story behind each approach. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: PWC126 - Minesweeper Game
item.description: Well documented solution to the Minesweeper Game task. Bonus you get Raku version as well.

item.title: PWC126 - Count Numbers
item.description: The best part of the blog is the performance matrix at the end showing 2 different approaches. Smart approach.

item.title: That One Is Mine: The (Perl and JS) Weekly Challenge #126
item.description: Dave making good use of multidimensional array to solve Minesweeper Game task. Clever coding.

item.title: I Sweep For No One
item.description: The blog title brought the smile on my face. I think Colin is giving Arne tough fight as far as the blog title is concerned. BY now, we have already seen the quality of technical blog every week. I can't thank you enough.

item.title: Count Minesweeper with Raku and Perl
item.description: Arne style of accepting input parameter for Minesweeper Game task is really cool. Great example showing the power of Perl and Raku. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Challenge 126
item.description: The highlight of the blog is the Raku solution using Hyper for parallel processing. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Count Numbers / MineSweeper game: The Weekly Challenge 126
item.description: Nice example of code reuse while dealing with Minesweeper Game. Well done.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 126: Minesweeper Game
item.description: I never understood the game before, I must confes. Thanks to the blog by Abigail, I can now say it is not too difficult.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 126: Count Numbers
item.description: Abigail shared a completely different aspect of the task that I wasn't aware of. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 126
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Count Numbers" and "Minesweeper Game" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 127
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Disjoint Sets" and "Conflict Intervals". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Monthly Report - July
item.description: Monthly report, little late though.

item.title: App::Easer enhancement
item.description: Patched the inconsistency how default-child and children behaves.

item.title: Template::Perlish enhancement
item.description: binmode option added and utf8 option is documented now.

item.title: Object::Pad review Yuki Kimoto's 2021-08-21 - Constructor argument
item.description: Yuki hands on experiment with Object::Pad.

item.title: Perl and Computer Science
item.description: Discord server for the purposes of discussing more academic Computer Science type topics, as they relate to Perl.

item.title: Making Taint support optional in Perl
item.description: Neil shares the idea of making taint support optional in Perl as currently being discussed.

item.title: Perl & Raku: Best frenemies
item.description: Mark showing the fun to port Perl code to Raku.

item.title: A dream realized
item.description: Damian's take on Corinna and encourage to look over RFC for Corinna.

item.title: Politics in Programming
item.description: Curtis discuss the design aspects of Corinna. You really don't want to miss it.

item.title: #526 - Politics in Programming?
item.description:
Hi there

I came across a blog post by Curtis, titled Politics in Programming. As always the case, it has touched sensitive topics. You may or may not agree with his point of view but it is worth a read, imho.

Let me confess, ever since Cor renamed to Corinna, I always double check if there is double "r" or double "n" in the name. I get it wrong all the time. Jokes apart, I am very happy that Corinna being discussed on so many different public platforms, a BIG thanks to Curtis and his team.

There was another topic discussed on Facebook, "Data structure in Perl". It brought back some good old memories when I was first introduced to Perl. I came from C background, so you would assume the transition would have been smooth. It wasn't the case with me. I had hard time to get my head around the "reference" in Perl. Once I passed that hurdle, the next disaster was waiting for me i.e. "regex". I had no clue about it before. It took me a while to get hold of it. Even after 22 years of working with Perl, I still find regex magic that I have never seen before, thanks to Abigail contributions to the weekly challenge. The next big thing I dealt after regex was "network programming". The best book to understand the subject is Network Programming with Perl by Lincoln D. Stein, imho.

Did you notice, I didn't mention about OO in Perl yet?

It is only because I got the opportunity to actually use OO programming very late in my career. The first book that I read on the subject was Object Oriented Perl by Damian Conway. It was the first book by Damian that I read and completely fallen in love with it. Of course, how can I miss the next one by Damian, Perl Best Practices. I am happy to see Damian giving thumbs up to the Corinna project headed by Curtis in his recent blog, A dream realized. About the future of OO in core Perl, I am not too worried as it is in safe hands now.

A fellow member of Team PWC, Adam Russell, started Discord server for the purposes of discussing more academic Computer Science type topics, as they relate to Perl. If you are keen to join then please follow the invitation.

School holiday is coming to end soon, at least in England, so ejoy while it lasts. Don't forget to keep safe distance and use mask in public place. Enjoy the rest of the newsletter.
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
